title: 22 Korean Beauty Products Under $15 That’ll Earn A Permanent Place In Your Routine
description: Including a hydrating lippie that reviewers are comparing to Tarte's Juicy Maracuja and YSL's Candy Glaze... (*adds to cart*)
content:
A waterproof mascara reviewers have hailed as a holy grail if you have short, straight eyelashes that don't seem to hold a curl. The slender, curved wand makes sure that even those sneaky, barely-there lashes get the attention they deserve — and if you already have some length to work with, this mascara gives you that extra oomph. And! If you need a good mascara remover (that's also under $15), here's one from the same brand. Promising review: "10 stars if I could! This is the only mascara that I've ever used that has actually been able to maintain a curl for my lashes. I'm blessed with long thick lashes, but sadly they point straight at the ground. Most mascaras that I’ve tried can’t seem to hold any of the curl from my lash curler, leaving me with dark smears under my eyes and droopy lashes not long after application. With this mascara… absolutely flawless. No transferring at all. Just wore it for the first time on a 8 hour flight and my lashes looked the exact same after a long nap under an eyemask as they did when I first applied. Seriously, this stuff works." —Samantha Anne

 Get it from Amazon for $14.07+ (available in five styles).



 A buildable Missha tinted BB cream that's a primer, foundation, concealer, AND sunscreen (with SPF 42 and PA+++)! It also offers some seriously hydrating skincare magic thanks to the hyaluronic acid and ceramides. If you're someone who wants to skip out on having a million different bottles on your vanity and simplify your beauty routine, this is THE one-and-done face product. In case you're not familiar with it, PA stands for "Protection Grade of UVA" and is a four-level rating system that's more common in Asia. In this case, PA+++ just means this product offers a high level of protection against UVA rays, which don't cause sunburn but rather cause the skin to turn brown. Promising review: "I've been using Missha BB cream for eight years now, and it's hands-down the best BB cream I've ever tried! What I love most is how lightweight it feels on my skin while still providing natural coverage that hides my redness and occasional blemishes without looking cakey. The staying power is impressive — I can apply it in the morning, and it still looks fresh by the end of my workday without needing touch-ups. After eight years of loyalty to this product, I can confidently say it's worth every penny!" —Daryna Get it from Amazon for $12.90 (available in seven shades). The shade range is unfortunately pretty limited for this product — if you're looking for another option in this price range, check out E.l.f's Camo CC Cream!
summary: The article discusses the top 22 Korean beauty products under $15, including waterproof mascara and a mascara remover from the same brand. These products are often praised for their ability to maintain a curl for their long, straight eyelashes. The Missha tinted BB cream is a combination of primer, foundation, concealer, and sunscreen, and offers some seriously hydrating skincare magic thanks to hyaluronic acid and ceramides. The product also offers protection against UVA rays, which don't cause sunburn but cause the skin to turn brown.
shortSummary: South Korean beauty products under $15 include waterproof mascara, BB cream, and a good mascara remover, offering excellent long-term curl and effective skincare options.

ABOUT APPLEBERRY LIP OIL: Our tinted lip glow oil is formulated with apple seed oil and raspberry fruit extract to instantly moisturize and keep lips smooth. This unique formula helps lips appear glossy, clear, and more kissable and youthful.
ENHANCED DURABILITY & LONG-LASTING HYDRATION : Our Lip Oil is designed for all-day wear, providing long-lasting moisture, strength, and resilience to keep your lips soft and supple. Its advanced formula ensures deep hydration without frequent reapplication, maintaining a vibrant, glossy finish. Clinical studies confirm its effectiveness, with 52.84% of hydration retained even after 24 hours, proving its superior longevity and lasting nourishment.

TRAVEL FRIENDLY: This compact and lightweight lip oil is perfect for travel. Take it with you wherever you go—on trips, to the office, to classes, and anywhere else!
ACHIEVE A VIBRANT: Non-peel lip tint for all-day makeup. Hydrating lip oil suits girls & women, offering red lip stain's long-lasting, waterproof color with lip gloss shine. Convenient lip oil set.

A dermatologist weighs in on whether zit stickers are worthwhile
The cardinal rule of acne is “don’t pick,” but when you’re faced with a whitehead that seems to have its own zip code, sometimes, all logic flies out the window. If you’ve broken the rules (and gone against dermatologists’ advice) by taking matters into your own hands, you may be left with the gory aftermath: An open wound leaking pus, oil and even blood.
Advertisement
Cleveland Clinic is a non-profit academic medical center. Advertising on our site helps support our mission. We do not endorse non-Cleveland Clinic products or services. Policy
Enter pimple patches, sometimes known as zit stickers, which may be able to help soothe your skin in a pinch. Dermatologist Amy Kassouf, MD, explains what these over-the-counter spot treatments can — and can’t — do for your skin troubles.
Pimple patches are small stickers made with a slightly gummy wound-healing gel called hydrocolloid. Larger versions are marketed as “blister bandages,” but they’re all designed to do the same thing: Help your skin heal faster.
“Pimple patches work by absorbing any drainage from the pimple and covering the wound to prevent further trauma to the site, such as picking,” Dr. Kassouf explains. “They work best on open, draining, healing pustules, papules and cysts.”
Of course, you know you’re not supposed to pick at your skin or pop zits. But if you’ve already committed this skin care sin, a pimple patch may be a helpful healer.
Most pimple patches need to be worn for a few hours in order to do their thing, so you may want to plan to apply yours before bed. Some versions are also designed to be inconspicuous enough to be worn during the day.
Before applying your pimple patch, make sure your skin is completely dry, as the patches won’t stick as well to wet skin. If your freshly picked pimple is leaking or oozing, be sure to cleanse the spot before application.
Advertisement
Simply apply the pimple patch over your zit — remember, they only work on open wounds — and leave it on for the recommended amount of time (which varies by product). When you peel it off, your blemish may be smaller and less inflamed.
For most people, pimple patches are, at worst, simply unhelpful — which is to say that they won’t make your acne worse, but they won’t make it better, either. If you have sensitive skin, though, you may want to steer clear of pimple patches.
“They do use a bit of adhesive to stick to your skin, so if you’re allergic or sensitive to adhesive, this may aggravate the skin surrounding the lesion,” Dr. Kassouf says.
And some brands use ingredients such as salicylic acid or tea tree oil to dry out pimples, which may also dry or irritate sensitive skin.
Though pimple patches can be very effective on existing lesions, they have significant limitations.
“Pimple patches don’t work at all on closed lesions or deeper lesions or even blackheads and whiteheads, which are called comedones,” Dr. Kassouf explains. “They are spot treatments for active bumps and have no ability to prevent acne from coming,” nor can they clear clogged pores or other precursors to acne flares.”
In other words, if you’re struggling with cystic acne, large-scale breakouts or other skin concerns, pimple patches aren’t going to do the trick.
There’s no real harm in using zit stickers — but they may not work, either, leaving you pimply and frustrated. “They’re really just wound healing dressings for a very specific type of lesion,” Dr. Kassouf says. “They can be helpful, but for overall acne treatment, there is little use for them.
Don’t fret, though. You’ve got options.
“There are a lot of great over-the-counter medications these days that do more for the money,” Dr. Kassouf says.
Advertisement
If your breakouts are related to an underlying issue like a hormonal imbalance, these treatments may not be enough for you. “If hormones are the issue, your dermatologist may have much better options for you,” Dr. Kassouf says.
Bottom line? Pimple patches can be a worthwhile option for certain, minor skin troubles, but don’t expect them to be a cure-all for your skin ailments.
Advertisement

Advertisement

argos_summary: A waterproof mascara has been praised for its ability to hold a curl for short, straight eyelashes, featuring a slender, curved wand that enhances lash appearance without smudging. Additionally, a tinted BB cream from Missha combines primer, foundation, concealer, and sunscreen, providing lightweight coverage and hydration, making it a versatile choice for simplifying beauty routines. Pimple patches, or zit stickers, are discussed as a potential solution for healing open acne lesions, though they have limitations and are not effective for all types of acne.
